title: Last Stone Weight
description: You are given an array of integers stones where stones[i] is the weight of the ith stone. We are playing a game with the stones. On each turn, we choose the heaviest two stones and smash them together. Suppose the heaviest two stones have weights x and y with x <= y. The result of this smash is: If x == y, both stones are destroyed, and If x != y, the stone of weight x is destroyed, and the stone of weight y has new weight y - x. At the end of the game, there is at most one stone left. Return the weight of the last remaining stone. If there are no stones left, return 0.

examples.explanation: We combine 7 and 8 to get 1 so the array converts to [2,4,1,1,1] then, we combine 2 and 4 to get 2 so the array converts to [2,1,1,1] then, we combine 2 and 1 to get 1 so the array converts to [1,1,1] then, we combine 1 and 1 to get 0 so the array converts to [1] then that's the value of the last stone.

brute-force.name: Brute Force
brute-force.description: Sort in every iteration to find heaviest stones.

steps.instruction: Define the function last_stone_weight that takes stones.
Loop while more than 1 stone exists.
steps.hint: Sort the stones to easily access the heaviest ones.
Remove the two largest stones from the end of the sorted list.

steps.instruction: If they differ, add the difference back.
steps.hint: If the stones are not equal, push the difference back into the list.
Return the remaining stone or 0 if none are left.

optimal.name: Optimal
optimal.description: Use a max heap (simulated with negative values) for efficiency.

steps.instruction: Import the heapq library and define the function last_stone_weight.
steps.hint: The heapq module is needed for heap operations.

steps.instruction: Negate all stone weights to use them in a min-heap as a max-heap.
steps.hint: Python's heapq only supports min-heaps, so we negate values to simulate a max-heap.

steps.instruction: Transform the list into a valid heap in-place.
steps.hint: The heapify function reorders the list to satisfy the heap property in O(n) time.

steps.instruction: Initialize a loop that runs as long as there is more than one stone left.
steps.hint: The game continues until 0 or 1 stone remains.

steps.instruction: Pop the heaviest stone from the heap.
steps.hint: The heaviest stone has the smallest negative value in the heap.

steps.instruction: Pop the second heaviest stone from the heap.
steps.hint: Use heappop again to get the next largest weight.

steps.instruction: Check if the two stones have different weights.
steps.hint: Since we use negative values, 'second > first' means the original weight of 'first' was greater.

steps.instruction: Push the difference of the two stones back into the heap.
steps.hint: The remaining weight is the difference between the heavier and the lighter stone.

steps.instruction: Ensure the heap is not empty by adding a zero if necessary.
steps.hint: This handles the case where all stones are destroyed.

steps.instruction: Return the absolute value of the remaining stone.
steps.hint: Negate the result back to its original weight using abs().
